ArticleInfo.ArticleTitle: Large-scale fabrication of polymer/Ag core–shell nanorod array as flexible SERS substrate by combining direct nanoimprint and electroless deposition

Affiliation.OrgDivision: Wuhan National Laboratory for Optoelectronics, School of Optical and Electronic Information
Affiliation.OrgName: Huazhong University of Science and Technology

Abstract.Heading: Abstract
Abstract.Para: We demonstrate a highly sensitive surface-enhanced Raman scattering (SERS) substrate, which consists of Ag nanoparticles (NPs) assembled on the surface of a nanopatterned polymer film. The fabrication route of a polymer/Ag core–shell nanorod (PACSN) array employed a direct nanoimprint technique to create a high-resolution polymer nanorod array. The obtained nanopatterned polymer film was subjected to electroless deposition to form a sea-cucumber-like Ag shell over the surface of the polymer nanorod. The morphology and structures of PACSNs were analyzed by using scanning electron microscopy and X-ray diffraction. The as-synthesized PACSNs exhibited a remarkable SERS activity and Raman signal reproducibility to rhodamine 6G, and a concentration down to 10−12 M can be identified. The effect of electroless deposition time of Ag NPs onto the polymer nanorod surface was investigated. It was found that the electroless deposition time played an important role in SERS activity. Our results revealed that the combination of direct nanoimprint and electroless deposition provided a convenient and cost-effective way for large-scale fabrication of reliable SERS substrates without the requirement of expensive instruments.

Section1.Heading: Introduction
Section1.Para: Surface-enhanced Raman scattering (SERS) spectroscopy has stimulated worldwide research interest as a great and powerful analytical technique for ultra-sensitive detection of molecules and biomolecules. It is now widely recognized that two different mechanisms are involved in SERS: (1) chemical enhancement caused by the charge transfer between the molecule and the adjacent metal surface; (2) the local electromagnetic enhancement in the vicinity of noble or transition metals due to the excitation of plasmonic surface modes by the incident visible light. Normally, the latter one is considered to be the main contributor to SERS enhancement, as it is several orders of magnitude larger than the chemical enhancement in most cases [1–3]. Strongly enhanced localized electromagnetic fields (also known as ‘hot spots’) at rough-surface [4–6] nanoparticle colloids [7] and periodic nanostructures [8–11] have been observed experimentally and verified by computational simulations. It is found that the rough-surface and isolated nanoparticle colloids can typically exhibit localized positions of high enhancement arising at sharp corners or at junctions of randomly formed protrusions [12]. However, these two show poor reproducibility of the SERS signal, which is not suitable for reproducible SERS measurements with a well-characterized enhancement factor [12]. Contrarily, periodic nanostructures show relatively a stable and highly reproducible SERS signal [13–15]. So far, the conventional techniques for fabricating periodic nanostructures have involved electron-beam lithography and dry reactive ion etching [16, 17], which are not commercially feasible for single-use disposable detection applications due to complicated nanofabrication processes and costly instruments.

Compared to photolithography, nanoimprint lithography (NIL) can fabricate large-scale nanostructures with a simple process, high throughput, and relatively low cost [18]. Especially, by using direct nanoimprint of a flexible polymer film, the number of process steps can be decreased and the expensive processes such as photolithography and inductively coupled plasma etching steps can be skipped. Also, Wu et al. have pointed out that polymeric material used as a SERS substrate is much more transmissive than a conventional silicon substrate in the visible and infrared regions, therefore reducing the absorption processes that can severely reduce both the excitation and emission efficiencies for Raman scattering [19]. In addition, the polymeric material can be easily molded into different shapes, such as nanopillars [20, 21], nanolenses [22], nanogratings [23], and nanocones [19, 24], while still keeping its mechanical strength.

Silver (Ag) nanoparticles (NPs) attached to a polymer substrate can adsorb analytes directly on their surfaces, leading to superior SERS sensitivity. Such hierarchical SERS substrates can be prepared by attaching metal nanoparticles onto the polymer substrate via methods such as sputter coating or electron-beam evaporation. Although the above two methods enable the substrate to possess extraordinary uniformity and high SERS sensitivity, they still suffer from some constraints, and one of them is the high cost in instruments. On the other hand, electroless deposition has been extensively used to produce Ag NPs for SERS due to its low cost and environment friendliness [25–27]. Furthermore, the Ag nanoparticles obtained by electroless deposition can have a very rough surface, which could provide vast hot spots over the whole substrate’s surface [1, 26, 28]. Therefore, it can be expected that direct nanoimprint combined with electroless deposition could be a convenient and cost-efficient way for mass production of stable and high-enhancement SERS substrates.

Here, we present that a large-scale polymer/Ag core–shell nanorod (PACSN) array could be fabricated by the combination of direct nanoimprint and electroless deposition without complicated processes and sophisticated instruments. The SERS activity was then evaluated by detecting the signal from Raman probe molecules, rhodamine 6G (R6G). The resulting new substrates show a remarkable SERS activity and Raman signal reproducibility. Meanwhile, the effect of electroless deposition time is identified on the basis of SERS performance evaluation, as well as the nanoscale structural characterizations.

Section2.Heading: Materials
Section2.Para: Polyolefin resin (PR, Obducat AB) was used as surface-patterned flexible substrate for the surface-enhanced Raman scattering (SERS). AgNO3, NaOH, NH3⋅H2O, SnCl2, anhydrous D-glucose, and rhodamine 6G were of analytical grade and purchased from Alfa Aesar. All chemicals were used as received. Deionized (DI) water (resistivity≥18.0 MΩ cm) was used for all the experiments.

Section2.Heading: Fabrication of polymer/Ag core–shell nanorod (PACSN) array
Section2.Para:
The fabrication process flow is illustrated in Fig. 1. A 2-in Si master stamp with a two-dimensional (2D) array of 300-nm-diameter holes (period=450 nm, depth=260 nm) was fabricated by traditional electron-beam lithography. Then the PR film was placed against the perfluorodecyltrichlorosilane-treated silicon master mold [29, 30] in a custom-designed nanoimprint machine. The nanoimprint process was done at 155 ∘C and 40 bar for 20 min. After demolding at room temperature, the flexible PR substrate was obtained.
Fig. 1
A schematic diagram showing the fabrication process of an array of polymer/Ag core–shell nanorods

Then, prior to the growth of Ag NPs, the patterned PR substrate was first treated with oxygen plasma (50 sccm, 25 mTorr, 50 W, 20 s) to improve the surface hydrophilicity of PR. Subsequently, the patterned PR substrate was immersed in 0.5 mM SnCl2 for 10 min to activate the surface for the following nucleation and growth of Ag NPs.

The electroless deposition of Ag NPs onto the activated patterned PR film was conducted using modified Tollen’s reagent. The Tollen’s reagent was obtained by adding 20 mL of 0.6 M aqueous solution of NaOH to 120 mL of 26 mM aqueous solution of AgNO3. The freshly formed colloidal silver oxide was dissolved by titrating with 38 % aqueous ammonia until the black silver oxide particles disappeared and the [Ag(NH3)2]+ complex had formed. Then, activated patterned PR film was immersed into 9 mL of the above [Ag(NH3)2]+ aqueous solution, and 9 ml glucose solution (10 mM) was added subsequently. The electroless deposition was operated for different periods of deposition time (90–330 s). Finally, the obtained PACSNs were thoroughly rinsed with DI water and dried in air.

Section2.Heading: Characterization and Raman spectroscopy measurements
Section2.Para: The morphologies of samples were characterized by scanning electron microscopy (SEM). X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns were recorded on a diffractometer with Cu Kα radiation (X’Pert Pro MPD, Philips). Raman microprobe measurements were made using a HR800-UV Horiba-Jobin Yvon spectrometer coupled with an Olympus metallographic microscope. The spectra measured on the samples were obtained using an Ar+ laser (λ=514 nm) as excitation with 1 % amplitude of 5 mW laser power. The spectra were collected using a 100× microscope objective (N.A.=0.9) with an average spot size of 1 μm in diameter. R6G was used as the reporter probe for the SERS measurements. The as-prepared substrates were immersed in 60 mL of R6G aqueous solutions of different concentrations for 6 h, then taken out and dried in the dark for SERS detection. The integration time for collecting a spectrum was 10 s.

Section2.Heading: Preparation and characterization of PACSN array
Section2.Para:
The principle of electroless plating is well known and explained in many other research papers. Basically, in the reaction, silver ions are reduced to silver atoms by accepting electrons; D-glucose molecules are oxidized to species containing carboxyl/carboxylate by donating electrons. The chemical reaction equation is described as follows [25]:
$$\begin{aligned} &\mbox{D-CHO} + 2\bigl[\mbox{Ag}(\mbox{NH}_{3})_{2}\bigr]^{+} + 3\mbox{OH}^{-} \\ &\quad \rightarrow 2\mbox{Ag}+ \mbox{D-COO}^{-} + 4\mbox{NH}_{3} + 2\mbox{H}_{2}\mathrm{O}. \end{aligned}$$

Hydrophilic surface treatment of PR can significantly influence the deposition of Ag NPs onto the nanopatterned polymer film. The basic nature of the PR film is hydrophobic (static water contact angle=121.0∘), which interrupts the Ag NPs seeding on the surface of PR. O2 plasma treatment is now a common method to make a polymer surface hydrophilic. This can be explained in that the improved surface hydrophilicity is induced by forming of new oxygen-containing groups on the surface, such as –OH, –OOH, etc., for these groups are hydrophilic [31, 32]. Thus, we adopted oxygen plasma to improve the surface hydrophilicity of PR, which resulted in a contact angle of less than 20∘. Then the deposition of Ag NPs on PR was carried out with a SnCl2 treatment. The microstructures of samples obtained with and without surface hydrophilic treatment are shown in Fig. 2a and b, respectively. It is found that the Ag NPs are tightly stacked to the surface of modified PR. As for the unmodified PR, Ag NPs are randomly and sparsely distributed over the PR film. Some Ag NPs are aggregated together on the top of the PR film instead of forming an Ag NP shell.
Fig. 2
The SEM image of Ag NPs on the PR with (a) and without (b) O2 plasma treatment

A large-area uniform PACSN array after deposition for 210 s is shown in Fig. 3a. It shows that the PACSN array is a 2D triangular lattice structure with an average diameter of 410 nm and an inter-rod distance of 40 nm. From a 30∘ tilt-view SEM image of the same PACSNs (Fig. 3b), it can be observed that the Ag NPs with sharp corners are roughly 80 nm in diameter and randomly stacked on the surface of PR nanorods to form a sea-cucumber-like shell.
Fig. 3
(a) The SEM image of PACSNs after depositing Ag NPs for 240 s. (b) The 30∘-tilted SEM image of PACSNs at a higher resolution. (c) XRD pattern of Ag NPs on the surface of PACSNs

Figure 3c shows the XRD pattern of PACSNs. The diffraction peaks at 2θ=38.1∘, 44.3∘, 64.5∘, and 77.3∘ can be indexed to (1 1 1), (2 0 0), (2 2 0), and (3 1 1) planes of the face-centered-cubic (fcc) phase (JCPDS No. 04-0783), respectively, confirming that the resultant nanosheets are well-crystallized Ag crystals.

Section2.Heading: SERS evaluation of PACSN array
Section2.Para:
Raman spectroscopy reveals the vibration hyperfine structures that are suitable for sensitive techniques to investigate surface adsorbates. Here, R6G was used as reference to verify the spectral efficiency of the new substrates. Figure 4a shows the SERS spectra of 10−7 M R6G on the PACSN substrates (deposited for 210 s) and 10−6 M R6G on a silver reference sample (obtained by electroless depositing Ag NPs onto the un-patterned PR film). All spectra show that the R6G molecule is characterized by seven dominant Raman peaks, centered at Raman shifts of 611, 771, 1189, 1360, 1508, 1573, and 1649 cm−1. It also indicates that the SERS performance improves significantly when the PACSN substrate is used. Figure 4b shows the SERS spectra of R6G with different concentrations adsorbed on the PACSN arrays. The spectral feature of R6G can be identified clearly, even at a concentration as low as 10−12 M. We use the intensity at 1649 cm−1, the aromatic C–C stretching vibrational mode [33], to quantitatively evaluate the analytical enhancement factor.
Fig. 4
(a) Comparison of SERS performance on PACSNs and flat Ag film treated with 10−7 M and 10−6 M R6G, respectively. (b) SERS spectra of PACSNs exposed to different R6G concentrations, ranging from 10−8 M to 10−12 M. (c) (i) Normal Raman spectrum of 20 μL of 10−3 M R6G aqueous solution on glass slide of 3 mm2; (ii) SERS spectrum of 60 μL of 10−10 M R6G aqueous solution on 12 mm2 PACSNs

The enhancement factor (EF) was calculated according to the formula
$$\mathrm{EF} = \frac{I_{\mathrm{SERS}}/N_{\mathrm{SERS}}}{I_{\mathrm{Nor}}/N_{\mathrm{Nor}}}, $$ where I SERS and I Nor represent the intensities of the same band of R6G (here, 1649 cm−1) of the SERS spectrum and the normal Raman spectrum, and N SERS and N Nor represent the corresponding numbers of molecules in the focused incident laser spot. In order to obtain the values of these four parameters, we follow the same procedures based on the published literature [19, 34, 35]. For the pure R6G film with an area of 3 mm2, considering the laser spot to be a circle with a diameter of 1 μm, the number of the R6G molecules illuminated by the laser (N Nor) is 3.1×10−9. For the estimation of N SERS and I SERS, 60 μL of 10−10 M R6G aqueous solution was dispersed on 12 mm2 PACSNs. Supposing that all R6G molecules are absorbed on the Ag nanosheet-assembled film, N SERS is estimated to be 184. In Fig. 4c, we get that I SERS and I Nor are 1500 units and 480 units, respectively. Thus, EF is calculated to be 5.3×107.

Many researches have shown that the surface morphology of nanostructures plays an important role in determining the SERS activity [36, 37]. Especially, nanostructures with small nanogaps and abrupt edges tend to generate more intense plasmonic coupling, and thus higher SERS enhancement [38–40]. Besides, the nanostructures with larger surface area can accommodate more probe molecules [41, 42]. Since surface roughness and surface area are influenced by electroless deposition time in this study, a series of PACSN substrates were operated for different deposition times (90–330 s) and the results are shown in Fig. 5a. The corresponding SEM images are presented in Fig. 5b. It can be seen that the Raman intensity (I) of the as-prepared substrates improved sharply with the reaction time from 90 s to 210 s and then decreased with the reaction time from 270 s to 330 s. This phenomenon can be ascribed to the co-action of the sub-10-nm gap between two Ag NPs on PACSN and the surface area of PACSN. For PACSNs with short reaction time (90 s), the surface of the polymer nanorod is covered sparsely with Ag NPs, resulting in low SERS signals. The process of electroless deposition would continue the deposition of silver onto already formed Ag NPs. As the deposition time increases to 150 s, the Ag NPs grow larger and tend to aggregate with a sub-10-nm gap between particles. Although there are a certain number of hot spots, the overall surface area of PACSNs is relatively small; only a small amount of analyte can be absorbed to the hot spots. Thus, the collected SERS signal is not high enough. When the deposition time increases to 210 s, Ag NP aggregates are more closely packed, resulting in a larger number of hot spots. At the same time, more analytes are able to be absorbed onto the hot spots due to the largely increased surface area. Consequently, maximum SERS signal intensities are obtained. On the other hand, for PACSNs after Ag deposition for 270 s and 330 s, the neighboring PACSNs tend to merge together and fill up the inter-rod gaps, which results in the reduction of hot spots. Thus, the value of I drops swiftly.
Fig. 5
(a) The SERS spectra of R6G collected on PACSNs with different electroless deposition times. (b) The corresponding SEM images of PACSNs with different deposition times

For practical SERS applications, signal reproducibility is one of the essential parameters. To test the signal reproducibility of our samples, SERS spectra of R6G molecules with a concentration of 10−7 M from six randomly selected places on the PACSNs were collected under identical experimental conditions. Figure 6a shows that the Raman spectra of R6G on the sample are enhanced greatly at each acquisition point. The relative standard deviation (RSD) of SERS intensity of PACSNs at six different sites is about 12.2 % for 612 cm−1, 11.4 % for 1360 cm−1, and 10.0 % for 1649 cm−1, which demonstrate the good uniformity and reproducibility of PACSNs. To further investigate the reproducibility of different substrates, another two substrates were tested and the results are shown in Fig. 6b and c, respectively. The three substrates show assembled SERS spectra. The intensities of 1649 cm−1 on three different PACSNs are plotted in Fig. 6d. The RSD of the band intensity for the peak at 1649 cm−1 is found to be smaller than 15 %, indicating the relatively good reproducibility of our method. However, there are still slight fluctuations in the peak intensities, which may be due to the non-uniform adsorption of Ag nanoparticles and/or R6G molecules.
Fig. 6
(a)–(c) SERS spectra of 10−7 M R6G obtained from six random points on three different PACSN substrates. (d) The intensities (heights) of 1649 cm−1 on three different PACSN substrates

Section1.Heading: Conclusions
Section1.Para: A large-scale PACSN array has been successfully prepared by electroless depositing Ag NPs onto a surface-patterned polymer film. The as-synthesized substrate shows high sensitivity with a 10−12 M detection limit for R6G. In particular, it is revealed that the electroless deposition time has an import impact on SERS activity. The combination of direct nanoimprint and electroless deposition will open a new avenue for large production of such SERS substrates in a convenient manner. The PACSNs are mechanically flexible and may have great potential in environment monitoring and other applications.
